notes.usage: Disqualifier-signal examples for each primary interview question. Use these as pattern prompts for probing. Some signals are automatic disqualifiers if confirmed; others are cautionary until probed and confirmed.

questions.trait_name: Empathy and Respect for Children as Individuals
questions.primary_question: Tell me about a time a child was having a hard emotional moment. What did you notice, and how did you respond?

examples: I raised my voice so they knew I meant business, and it worked.
Sometimes you need to be stern and scare them a little so they stop.
I told them if they keep crying they’re going to miss the fun activity.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: When you say you raised your voice or scared them a little, what exactly did you say and how did the child react?

examples: Kids that age don’t really have boundaries, they just need direction.
They were being dramatic. If you give in, they learn they can control you.
I don’t do the whole feelings thing too much. We have to keep things moving.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: How do you balance moving things along with honoring a child’s boundaries and emotional needs in the moment?

examples: Some kids are just bad. You can tell who has no discipline at home.
Certain parents create these behaviors, then we have to deal with it.
These kids are so entitled now.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What do you think the child was communicating, and what support do you believe helps children who struggle like that?

examples: I was already at my limit that day, so I just snapped a little.
I felt my blood boiling, so I had to shut it down fast.
If a kid pushes long enough, you’re going to react.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What did 'snapped' look like exactly, and what do you do to prevent that from happening again?

examples: Rules are nice, but real life is different. You do what you have to do.
Sometimes you just pick them up and move them even if they don’t like it.
Licensing doesn’t understand what it’s really like.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What boundaries or safety standards do you consider non-negotiable even when it’s hectic?

examples: Honestly I’m just tired of the constant crying and drama.
At this point I don’t have the patience like I used to.
I’m burned out, but that’s childcare.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What are you doing today to recover and protect your patience and regulation at work?

questions.primary_question: Tell me about a time you felt overwhelmed with children present. How did you manage yourself?

examples: I had to yell to get everyone to listen.
I get loud when I need control. It’s the only thing that works sometimes.
I’m not proud of it, but I can’t deal with chaos.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What does 'get loud' mean specifically, and what would you do differently next time?

examples: I told them they were acting like babies.
I said, 'Do you want me to call your mom?' and they stopped.
I made an example out of one kid so the others would behave.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What was your intention with that comment, and how do you think it impacts a child’s dignity and safety?

examples: I don’t really focus on feelings when things are chaotic. They need structure.
Kids need to learn the world doesn’t stop for their emotions.
In that moment I just needed compliance so we could move on.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: How do you keep structure while still respecting a child’s emotional state and boundaries?

examples: I don’t like people telling me how to handle my classroom.
Every director has their own opinion. I just do what works.
I’m not the kind of person who needs someone watching over me.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: Tell me about a time a supervisor asked you to change something. What did you change and why?

examples: Some kids are just too much. They ruin it for everyone.
Parents don’t teach manners anymore, so we’re stuck dealing with it.
These families expect miracles.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: When you feel that way, what helps you stay respectful and child-centered in the moment?

examples: Sometimes you have to do what you have to do, even if it’s not the textbook way.
Licensing rules are great until you’re alone with too many kids.
We can’t follow every rule when it’s chaos.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: Which safety standards do you consider non-negotiable even under stress?

examples: I’m just over it. I’m tired of being overwhelmed every day.
I’ve been doing this too long to pretend it doesn’t get to me.
I need a job where I’m not constantly stressed.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What specific steps are you taking to recover your resilience and regulation?

questions.trait_name: Respect for Children’s Personal Rights and Safety
questions.primary_question: Tell me about a time you had to be mindful of a child’s safety, body, or boundaries.

examples: I’m not worried about little things like personal space. They’re kids.
Boundaries are important, but sometimes they don’t get a choice.
They’ll be fine. A little discomfort isn’t harm.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: How do you decide when a child does or doesn’t get a choice about their body or boundaries?

examples: If they won’t move, you look them in the eyes and make them.
I held their arms so they’d stop hitting. You have to sometimes.
I carried them out even though they were fighting me.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What alternatives did you try before physical control, and how did you ensure dignity and safety?

examples: Licensing is overly strict and doesn’t match reality.
I’ve worked places that did it differently and it was fine.
Those rules are more about paperwork than kids.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: Which safety and boundary expectations do you believe should be followed no matter what?

examples: I already know what’s safe. I don’t need someone correcting me on that.
I trust my instincts over policies.
I don’t like being second-guessed on safety.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: If a supervisor asked you to change a safety practice you believed was fine, what would you do next?

examples: Some kids use boundaries to manipulate adults.
Parents complain about everything now.
Families exaggerate safety concerns.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: How do you stay respectful when you feel a concern is exaggerated?

examples: It’s exhausting to be careful about every little thing.
Sometimes you don’t have the bandwidth to do all that extra.
I’m tired of walking on eggshells.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What support or strategies help you maintain careful, respectful practice consistently?

questions.primary_question: Tell me about a time you received feedback you didn’t expect. What happened next?

examples: I listened, but I didn’t change anything because I knew I was right.
I don’t take feedback well from people who haven’t done the job.
I’m not really into being micromanaged.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What specific change did you make based on that feedback, and how did you verify it improved anything?

examples: I got really upset, so I walked out of the conversation.
I told them off because it wasn’t fair.
I get defensive when people criticize me.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: How do you handle correction in the moment so you stay regulated and respectful?

examples: Policies change all the time, but I do what works regardless.
Sometimes you have to bend rules to manage kids.
I’m not going to follow something I don’t agree with.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: Which expectations do you see as non-negotiable, and how do you respond when policy conflicts with your preference?

examples: Directors always have favorites, so feedback isn’t objective.
Management just wants control.
Parents complain and leadership caves, so teachers get blamed.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: Tell me about a time you disagreed but still implemented feedback respectfully. What did that look like?

examples: I’m tired of changing things every time leadership changes.
I don’t have energy for constant feedback anymore.
At this point I’m set in my ways.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What would help you stay open and flexible with ongoing coaching?

questions.primary_question: Tell me about a time something didn’t go as planned at work and your role in it.

examples: They kept questioning me, but I had already handled it.
I don’t like being monitored if I’m doing my job.
Documentation is just bureaucracy.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: How do you respond when a supervisor asks for documentation or a change in how you do something?

examples: Sometimes you skip steps because you don’t have time.
We couldn’t follow everything perfectly, but that’s normal.
Rules are flexible depending on staffing.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: Which safety and respect expectations do you consider non-negotiable even when short-staffed?

examples: Parents overreact, so we stopped taking complaints seriously.
Families lie and then blame teachers.
Coworkers were lazy so it fell on me.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: When a complaint happens, how do you stay respectful and accountable while investigating what’s true?

examples: I just didn’t care that day.
I’m not going to stress myself out for a job.
I’m over being the only responsible person.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What do you do to maintain reliability and follow-through when you feel drained?

examples: I got irritated and said some things, but it needed to be said.
I was so frustrated I left early.
When people mess up, I snap.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What does 'snap' look like for you, and what strategies do you use to prevent it?

questions.primary_question: Tell me about a challenging situation you worked through with another adult.

examples: People are so sensitive. I just say it how it is.
Most coworkers don’t pull their weight.
Parents are the reason kids act this way.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: How do you deliver direct feedback without creating fear, shame, or hostility?

examples: I prefer to do my own thing and not be corrected.
I don’t like being told what to do by leads.
I’m not a team player if the team is incompetent.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: Tell me about a time you disagreed with a lead but still aligned with the team. What did you do?

examples: I can get heated, but that’s because I care.
If someone disrespects me, I’m going to respond.
Conflict makes me lose my patience.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What do you do to stay regulated when conflict escalates?

examples: In chaos you do what you have to do.
I don’t have time to coordinate. I handle kids my way.
Communication is nice, but it slows everything down.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: How do you ensure safety and respectful handling when you’re moving fast with other adults involved?

examples: I’m tired of people. I’d rather not deal with adults at all.
I’m done trying to make teams work.
I don’t have energy for teamwork drama.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What helps you stay collaborative and respectful even when you’re tired or frustrated?

questions.primary_question: Tell me something you’ve learned over time that changed how you approach children.

examples: Feelings are fine, but they need to toughen up.
Boundaries are an adult concept.
Kids don’t really understand rights, they just need direction.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: How do you treat a child’s boundaries and emotional experience as non-negotiable in your day-to-day?

examples: I learned you have to be strict early or they’ll run you.
You can’t let them win, so you have to shut it down.
They need to feel consequences so they stop.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: When you say 'shut it down' or 'strict,' what does that look like in your words and tone?

examples: I’ve learned rules are flexible depending on the situation.
You can’t follow every guideline and still run a class.
Policies are nice, but real life is different.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: Which safety and respect expectations do you see as non-negotiable regardless of context?

examples: I don’t really change my approach. It works.
Trainings are repetitive. I don’t need them.
I trust my instincts more than coaching.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: Tell me about a time you changed a habit after coaching and what improved as a result.

examples: I’ve learned to stop caring as much or you’ll lose your mind.
I’m just trying to get through the day.
You can’t get emotionally invested.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What helps you maintain care and patience without burning out?

examples: You can’t fix what parents do at home, so you stop trying.
Some kids just don’t want to behave.
Parents are the problem most of the time.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: How do you keep respect for families while still holding boundaries and supporting the child?

questions.primary_question: Tell me how you physically care for infants or toddlers during routines like diapering, feeding, or comforting.

examples: You have to hold them still or it’ll never get done.
If they fight diapering, I just get it over with.
Sometimes you restrain them a little so you can finish.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What does 'hold them still' look like physically, and what gentler alternatives do you use first?

examples: They’re too young to have boundaries.
I don’t ask, I just do it. They’re infants.
They don’t understand consent, so it’s not really relevant.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: How do you respect an infant’s cues and bodily boundaries even when they can’t verbalize?

examples: Infants are a lot. It’s draining.
I’m over the constant crying.
I don’t really have the patience for babies anymore.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What do you do to keep your patience and gentleness steady throughout the day?

examples: You can’t do everything perfectly when you’re busy.
Sometimes you skip the extra steps.
If you follow every rule, you’ll fall behind.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: Which safety and handling practices do you consider non-negotiable, even when you’re behind?

examples: Hold on, I need to check on the kids real quick.
I’m at work right now, but it’s fine, they’re playing.
Let me mute for a second, I have to handle something with a child.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: Are you currently responsible for supervising children right now during this interview?

questions.primary_question: How do you figure out what a nonverbal child needs when they’re upset?

examples: Sometimes they just cry for no reason.
You try everything and it’s still not enough.
It’s exhausting when they can’t tell you.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What helps you stay patient and regulated when the crying continues and nothing works quickly?

examples: They’ll stop eventually. I don’t feed into it.
Crying is just what they do.
I don’t pick them up every time. They need to learn.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: How do you decide when to respond and how to do it while honoring the child’s emotional needs and safety?

examples: If it goes on too long, I get irritated.
After a while I just need it to stop.
I can only take so much crying.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What do you do in the moment to keep your tone and body language calm when you feel irritated?

examples: I put them somewhere safe and let them cry it out.
I separate them and ignore it until they stop.
Sometimes they just need to cry it out, and you move on.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: How do you ensure the child feels emotionally safe and respected while they’re upset?

questions.primary_question: Tell me about a time a child’s behavior was challenging for you. How did you approach it?

examples: I raised my voice so everyone understood it’s serious.
I told them they were being a baby.
I embarrassed them a little so they wouldn’t do it again.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What did you say exactly, and how do you think that impacted the child’s dignity and emotional safety?

examples: I don’t negotiate with kids.
Feelings don’t change expectations.
They don’t get a choice when I’ve given an instruction.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: How do you enforce expectations while still respecting a child’s boundaries and emotional needs?

examples: That kid is always a problem.
Some kids just don’t care.
The parents are the issue.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What do you think the behavior was communicating, and how do you keep respect for the child and family?

examples: I got fed up and had to shut it down.
I can only take so much.
I was at my limit, so I got strict.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: When you’re at your limit, what specific strategies help you stay calm and non-reactive?

examples: Rules are fine, but sometimes you have to handle it your way.
Licensing doesn’t know what it’s like with real kids.
We can’t follow everything perfectly in the moment.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: Which boundaries and safety expectations do you consider non-negotiable even when behavior is intense?

examples: I’m tired of the same behaviors every day.
I don’t have patience like I used to.
I’m just trying to survive the day.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What are you doing currently to rebuild patience and resilience so you can show up calmly?

questions.primary_question: Tell me about a time your plan changed because of children’s needs. What did you do?

examples: Kids need to learn to follow the schedule.
They have to adapt, not me.
If you let them derail the plan, you lose control.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: How do you balance structure with responsiveness to children’s emotional needs and cues?

examples: It stresses me out when plans change.
I get irritated when things don’t go as planned.
I don’t do well with disruptions.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What do you do in the moment to stay calm and prevent frustration from affecting your tone or choices?

examples: If they keep pushing, I get strict so they stop.
I shut it down fast so the rest of the class doesn’t get ideas.
Sometimes you have to be firm so they know you’re in charge.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What does 'strict' or 'shut it down' look like specifically in your words and tone?

examples: They’re always pushing limits.
Some kids do it on purpose.
Parents don’t teach structure at home.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What do you believe children are communicating when plans disrupt, and how do you stay respectful?

examples: I’m tired of adjusting all day.
It’s nonstop and I’m kind of over it.
I don’t have the energy to be flexible anymore.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: What steps are you taking to restore your patience and flexibility so children still get calm support?

examples: You do what you have to do when plans fall apart.
Sometimes the rules slow you down too much.
Policies don’t always work in real life.
disqualifier_signals.probe_to_confirm: Which safety and respectful treatment standards do you consider non-negotiable no matter what?
